trial_identification.studytitle: The effectivess of a support model for elderly families with dementia
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Family Care as Collaboration: The Effectiveness of a Rehabilitation Model for Elderly Families with Dementia. A randomised controlled intervention study and qualitative process research

interventions.interventions: Duration of study: 24 months Intervention group: Family care coordinator, geriatrician and individually tailored and need-based support activities (24 months). Families met the family care co-ordinator and the geriatrician at the beginning of the intervention and after that when needed (need-based and individually tailored consultations, in-home visits and follow-up calls) Goal-orientated peer support group meetings for caregivers ( 5 meetings with 8-10 participants in two months' intervals during the first intervention year, each meeting for 5 hours, including peer support sessions of 2 hours and recreational elements.Spouses with dementia had their own rehabilitation groups at the same time.
interventions.comparator: Control group: active (standard care: usual services provided for patients/ clients in community care by the municipal social and health care system)

primaryOutcome.outcome: Time to long term institutional care (the period in community care) from enrolment of the couples in the study to long term institutional care of people with dementia

secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline and at 6 and 12 months after randomisation
At baseline and at 6 and 12 months after randomisation

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Quality of life of spouse caregivers
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At baseline and at 6 and 12 months after randomisation

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Use of services and service expenditures

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Family: A spouse caring his/ her partner with dementia, living in the City of Helsinki, FinlandPatient: the minimum score of 1 in Clinical Dementia Rating Scale (CRD) and the maximum score of 24 in Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE).
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Either spouse had some severe disease (e.g. cancer) that might lead to institutionalisation or death in near future.

trial_design.concealment: The couples were recruited by newspaper announcements and from a compensation register for Alzheimer Disease drug costs of the Social Insurance Institution. Eligibility of couples were assessed by research nurses and further confirmed by researchers. Allocation was done by central randomisation by computer

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The purpose of the study was to determine whether it is possible to postpone long term institutional care of spouses with dementia and support spouse caregivers' psycological well-being and quality of life. Additionally, the effects of the intervention on total usage and expenses of social and health care services were analysed.
